discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CF
C & F are correct
https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/personally-identifiable-information-pii.asp#toc-how-pii-is-stolen

I agree with the answer being C & D. Some are over-analyising it feels like. PCI may be a standard, but it still includes rules/regulations that need to be complied with to properly protect that data.
From Meyers
"Protected health information (PHI) is basically any PII that
involves a person’s health status, medical records, and healthcare
services they have received. (The CompTIA Acronyms list spells
out PHI as personal health information, but protected is the correct
term.)
• Payment Card Industry (PCI) is a common shorthand for the
Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS), a
rigorous set of rules for systems that accept, transmit, process, or
store credit/debit card payments."

PII includes, but is not limited to, Social Security numbers, passport numbers, driver's license numbers, addresses, email addresses, photos, biometric data, or any other information that can be traced to one individual. Medical, educational, financial, and employment information all fall under PII.

Selected Answer: CD
Answer is C and D. Just learn to read questions carefully and you’ll see why.

Answer is PII. PCI compliance is a standard and is generally mandated for credit card companies. But it is a compliance guideline for companies to adhere to in regards to credit card transactions. 

Question is most likely wanting IT to protect PATIENT medical and financial data. PII would include financial information and PHI would include all medical.
Financial=PCI isnt it?

comments.content: Yes but PCI isn't regualted data it is a standard, it's a trick question basically
PCI is regulated data according to their course outline. It is not government regulated data.
I believe PCI is a standard, not a regulation.

questions.question_text: A healthcare institute has asked the IT department to help protect medical and financial data. Which of the following regulations is the healthcare provider MOST concerned about? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Surely this is A? "UPS monitoring is the process of monitoring the different metrics of UPS devices in a network, including voltage, current, battery status, and charge, so they are always up, available, and working." Wheras this is from the link given as the source "A Safety Data Sheet (SDS) is a document produced in alignment with the UN’s Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals (GHS) that the manufacturer, importer, or distributor of a chemical product is required to provide to downstream users. An SDS needs to have a specific 16-section format (see below), and the process of creating a properly formatted SDS is known as SDS authoring."

So the UPS monitor literally monitors current, whereas the MSDS is a data sheet about chemicals..
B is correct MSDS is related to identify change in environment

Selected Answer: A
https://www.manageengine.com/network-monitoring/ups-monitoring.html

Selected Answer: A
UPS monitor

Just because the question has the word "environment" in it, doesn't mean that we're talking about the Earth's environment here. It's like whomever answered this didn't both to read the entire question.

Selected Answer: A
MSDS is Material Safety Data Sheet, it has nothing to do with electrical monitoring.
I think D is the answer.
Really losing any faith with exam topics... No longer trust this web site,

I mean, it's embarrassing seeing how blatantly wrong this is, but the people making money off of this probably aren't doing it to get rich so much as avoid being homeless.
Answer is UPS monitor. MSDS is just a document listing hazardous materials and stuff.

The MSDS lists the hazardous ingredients of a product, its physical and chemical characteristics (e.g. flammability, explosive properties), its effect on human health, the chemicals with which it can adversely react, handling precautions, the types of measures that can be used to control exposure, emergency and first aid procedures, and methods to contain a spill. When new regulatory information, such as exposure limits, or new health effects information becomes available, the MSDS must be updated to reflect it.

comments.content: They do give the wrong answer because comptia will not allow a site like these to exist. as far as what some people said on the comments. The good thing about this site is it gives discussion.
At least you know it's wrong and you can learn what the correct answer is...

discussion.content: They are just taking us for fool

questions.question_text: Which of the following identifies changes in the environment, such as alternating current failure?

Users are reporting slow connections on their mobile devices when trying to download large data files from the network servers, but users on wired connections are not having any issues. A network technician notices multiple alerts about wireless access points going offline, and several devices connecting to the WLAN are unable to authenticate successfully. Which of the following issues are the mobile users experiencing?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
As users try to download large data files from the network server, the wireless network is most likely overloaded.

Selected Answer: A
I strongly believe it is A

choices.B: Open a run command and then type the application name.
choices.D: Uninstall the program after saving any associated data and reinstall the program.
choices.A: Open the application with administrative privileges.
choices.C: Reboot the computer into safe mode and try to open the program.

discussion.content: Surely you'd try it first with Admin priviledges since it takes literally a few seconds, then reinstall if nothing else works?

Selected Answer: D
This would be A if it were the TECHNICIAN troubleshooting, but the question asks "which of the following should the USER try first to resolve this issue", so we have to assume they don't have access to admin mode. It's a petty trick, but it does change the answer to D since that's the only thing they really would be able to do.
I'll have to assume it's D. I work for a MSP and many of our client's GPO policies prevent user's from both uninstalling/reinstalling software.

Selected Answer: A
I thought A - it doesn't say the user works in a corporate environment (in which they'd probably be restricted from Admin mode), so I would try this first before uninstalling it.
It's A

questions.question_text: A Microsoft application will not open when a user clicks on it. Instead, the following error message pops up: This application has crashed. Would you like to send an error report to Microsoft? Which of the following should the user try FIRST to resolve this issue?

Joe, a user, returns his computer to the technician who performed a virus removal on it the week before. Joe states that several symptoms have returned.
Which of the following should the technician have covered previously as part of the original repair?

discussion.content: You can never assume a scenario, only go by what the text says. It says the virus was removed so assume it was removed.
A makes sense, since it says a week before, meaning there are days that the symptoms didn't appear, computer works fine. Then user might have done something again to make the symptoms recur
The user obviously clicked on something he's not supposed to and got another malware infection...

The question was good but still a little vague for someone who understands that C could cause the issue too. But otherwise A makes sense. At the same time though how do we tell he did educate the user or forgot to disable system restore?. Maybe the customer was careless or forgot the training as this happens over a extended period. Which then does point to A because it would take longer than a week for a end user to forget enough in most cases to repeat the same error in such a short time.

I believed it was C however the way i see it, if C was the right answer it would imply the technician was incompetent and didnt do his job properly and im sure that is not what they would imply..... but like i said thats how i see it
A by a longshot, in my opinion. It's just really likely you forgot to tell him what not to click on to give him a virus then all of those other complicated things.

I think it is C. Considering that many of the "same" virus symptoms came back indicates a high possibility that the virus was saved in the system restore. That means the technician forgot to disable the system restore.
I thought it was C. doesn't say anywhere that Joe was the reason for the Malware returning. It could have been due to not disabling system restore....

comments.content: The answer is definitely A, when you refer to the steps to take in order to remove a malware, Educate the User is in last position, If Joe were to be educated about the malware symptoms by the Tech, He wouldn't be back the following week with the same problem again.

discussion.content: Well, I strongly believe ans should be C.
